RandomFacts.fact: Strengths is the longest word with only one vowel.
Redheads typically need about 20% more anesthesia than people with different hair color.
As of 2024, Madagascar has a larger population than Australia.
The most frequently purchased items on Amazon (2024) are the Apple Air Tags and the Stanley tumbler.
Google Images was inspired after Jennifer Lopez wore a then-scandalous green dress to the 2000 Grammy Awards.
The first free public library was founded in Peterborough, New Hampshire in 1833.
Dr. Seuss's book Green Eggs and Ham was banned in China because it was thought to portray Marxism in a negative light.
A single litter of kittens can have more than one father.
After the U.S. president and vice president, the postmaster general is the next highest-paid federal government employee.
Lake Chargo-ggagoggm-anchaug-gagoggcha-ubunagun gamaugg is the longest place-name in the United States.
Even though the Statue of Liberty is on Liberty Island, it is closer to New Jersey.
Every time you shuffle a randomized deck of cards, it's likely that you have created a unique arrangement.
Toilet paper was first produced in the late 800's AD in China.
A squid's brain is torus-shaped, and its esophagus runs through it.
Surgeon Serge Voronoff grafted monkey testicle tissue onto men in the 1920s.
The deepest hole ever drilled is the Kola Superdeep Borehole.
Bananas are slightly radioactive due to potassium content.
A bear named Wojtek enlisted in the Polish army and reached the rank of Corporal.
The size comparison between an atom and a grain of sand is like that between a grain of sand and Earth.
Liechtenstein and Uzbekistan are the only doubly-landlocked countries in the world.
American Airlines saved $40,000 annually by removing one olive from first-class salads in 1987.
Before becoming a painter, Bob Ross was a military drill sergeant.
Around 200 corpses are left on Mount Everest, many used as markers for climbers.
A restaurant in Pensacola, Florida, called McGuire Irish Pub has more than $500,000 worth of dollar bills hanging from the walls and ceiling.
The old distress signal 'SOS' does not stand for 'Save Our Souls' or 'Save Our Ships.'
Beaver anal secretions known as castoreum have been used as a vanilla flavor substitute.
Fernando Tatis Sr. is the only MLB player to hit two grand slams in a single inning.
The hottest temperature ever recorded on Earth was in El Azizia, Libya (136°F in 1922).
Anton syndrome is a rare condition where blind people are unaware of their blindness.
Taking a warm shower increases dopamine flow, leading to more creativity.
The Outer Banks off North Carolina's coast is called 'The Graveyard of the Atlantic.'
Lake Superior has a larger land mass than the entire country of Scotland.
The mathematical symbol for division (÷) is called an obelus.
Abraham Lincoln was a local wrestling champion before his political career.
Point Nemo in the Pacific is closer to the ISS than to any land mass.
The 'Hollywood' sign originally read 'Hollywoodland.'
The words 'raise' and 'raze' are both homophones and antonyms.
Twister was the first movie released on DVD.
Shaquille O'Neal walked away from a $40 million Reebok deal to sign with Wal-Mart.
Andre Agassi won 10 of 11 matches against Boris Becker by noticing a 'tick' in Becker's serve.
The Spanish word 'esposas' means both 'wives' and 'handcuffs.'
Babe Ruth hit more home runs in the 1920 and 1927 seasons than any team.
The voice actors for Mickey and Minnie Mouse got married in real life in 1991.
The average person spends about one full year sitting on the toilet.
Mauna Kea is taller than Mt. Everest when measured from its base on the ocean floor.
The seven successive Tour de Frances from 1999 to 2005 have no official winner due to doping scandals.
There are no muscles in your fingers; muscles in your palm and forearm control finger movements.
Contemporary names such as Jessica, Olivia, and Miranda were created by William Shakespeare.
The space between your eyebrows is called the glabella.
A pitcher can record 4 strikeouts in one inning in baseball due to a dropped third strike.
A blue whale's heartbeat can be heard from over 2 miles away.
Potatoes were the first vegetable to be grown in space.
Benin has the highest birth rate of twins in the world.
Pepsi gets its name from 'pepsin,' a digestive enzyme.
J.K. Rowling’s original Harry Potter pitch was rejected by 12 different publishers before Bloomsbury accepted it.
Over 2000 years ago, Eratosthenes estimated the Earth’s circumference using math. Without ever leaving Egypt, he was accurate to within 2%.
A bowler named James Blackstone once received a score of 299.5 after a pin cracked in half on the last frame. The bottom half of the pin remained standing, while the top half fell over.
The year 46 BC, known as the 'year of confusion,' was 445 days long. Julius Caesar added three extra months in order to make his Julian calendar line up with the seasonal year.
The movie The Shawshank Redemption has the highest user rating out of any film on IMDB. It’s adapted from a Stephen King novella 'Rita Hayworth and Shawshank Redemption.'
Hippopotamuses use two auditory systems: ears for sounds in the air, and their jawbones to conduct sounds underwater.
The most expensive book ever purchased was Leonardo Da Vinci's 'Codex Leicester,' bought by Bill Gates for $30.8 million.
Star quarterback Brett Favre's first NFL completion was to himself for a loss of 7 yards.
A species of wood frog in Alaska can hold its bladder for 8 months, using the urine to survive while it hibernates.
The human body sheds over 30,000 dead skin cells every minute.
The US sends Cuba a $4500 check each year for Guantanamo Bay, which Cuba has refused to accept since 1953.
It would take about 2,000,000 mosquito bites to lose two liters of blood, a life-threatening amount.
MLB catcher Harry Chiti was the first player to be traded for himself after a disappointing stint with the Mets.
Procrastination is more often linked to poor 'mood management' rather than laziness or time management.
In the 18th century, the British called cucumbers 'cowcumbers,' thinking they were only suitable for animal food.
Kool-Aid was invented in Hastings, Nebraska, in 1927, and its inventor received a dollar a day for his work.
A dog named Hachiko waited at Shibuya Station in Tokyo for his deceased owner for 9 years, becoming a symbol of loyalty.
Jellyfish are 95% water and are related to sea anemones and corals.
Cats have over 20 muscles that control their ears.
Each year, the Eiffel Tower grows 6 inches taller due to thermal expansion of its iron structure.
Each year, an estimated 22 billion dollars of U.S. currency goes missing, mostly due to aging, theft, or destruction.
The first video ever uploaded to YouTube was titled 'Me at the zoo' and was uploaded by co-founder Jawed Karim in 2005.
Starbucks serves over 4 million customers daily in 32,000 stores across 78 countries.
The average person will spend six months of their life waiting for red lights to turn green.
In 1977, a scientist sent a series of radio messages into space, known as the 'Arecibo message,' in hopes of making contact with extraterrestrial life.
On average, it takes about 66 days to form a new habit.
The word 'sneeze' comes from the Middle English word 'snesen,' which means to 'to snort or sneeze.'
Peacocks are not truly blue but have a unique structure that reflects light to create their vibrant colors.
Humans and giraffes have the same number of neck vertebrae – seven.
The world's oldest known 'your mom' joke is 3,500 years old and comes from ancient Babylon.
There are more stars in the universe than grains of sand on all the Earth's beaches.
More than 40% of the world's population has never made or received a phone call.
In 1971, a man named Peter Glaskin made a 3-hour flight in a balloon, breaking the world record for the longest hot air balloon flight.
The UK has a higher population of pets than children.
A snail can sleep for 3 years at a time.
Flamingos can only eat with their heads upside down.
Pineapples take about 2-3 years to grow.
The world's first known photograph was taken in 1826 by Joseph Nicéphore Niépce.
The tongue is the only muscle in the body that is only attached at one end.
Cows have best friends and can become stressed if they are separated.
Venus is the hottest planet in our solar system, despite being the second closest to the Sun.
A group of flamingos is called a 'flamboyance.'
The lifespan of a single taste bud is about 10-14 days.
The first animated feature film was Disney's 'Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs,' released in 1937.
Horses and cows sleep while standing up.
Polar bears have black skin under their white fur to absorb heat from the sun.
Dolphins have their own unique signature whistles to identify each other.
The inventor of the Pringles can is buried in one.
Bananas are technically berries, but strawberries are not.
A baby octopus is the size of a pea when it is born.
The first fruit to be eaten on the moon was an apple.
The world's largest desert is Antarctica.
An octopus has three hearts.
A group of owls is called a parliament.
In ancient Rome, it was considered a sign of leadership to be born with a crooked nose.
A jiffy is an actual unit of time, equal to 1/100th of a second.
Butterflies taste with their feet.
The average person has about 100,000 hairs on their head.
Hawaii is the only U.S. state that grows coffee.
In Japan, there are more pets than children.
Rats laugh when they are tickled.
The heart of a shrimp is located in its head.
Goldfish can live up to 40 years in captivity.
Sloths can hold their breath longer than dolphins.

The average person walks the equivalent of five times around the world in their lifetime.
Wombat poop is cube-shaped.
It takes eight minutes and twenty seconds for light from the sun to reach Earth.
Humans share 50% of their DNA with bananas.

There are more than 2,000 species of fruit flies.

Octopuses have been known to use tools.
